story:
Hi everyone!

In August 2020, my Dad was diagnosed with prostate cancer (stage 5). At the point of being diagnosed the cancer had already spread and since then the cancer has spread further. Unfortunately, my Dad is just one of many people who have 'slipped through the net' at the doctors. For years my Dad has had symptoms and not once did the doctors encourage or ask my Dad to get tested. This simply isn't good enough.¬†

I'm doing these challenges to raise money for an amazing cause but even more so to raise awareness of prostate cancer. If you don't feel something is quite right, even after going to your GP please ask for a 2nd opinion or ask for further investigation. Please, please, please! I can't emphasise this enough. So many men and families are being the victim of negligence through their GP and it simply isn't good enough. My Dad has had symptoms for years and believed the words of his GP, like anyone would. Unfortunately, believing those words of his GP have resulted in an extremely late diagnosis of prostate cancer. My Dad was never encouraged to be tested, never received a reminder letter to be screened. Absolutely nothing. Please don't rely on reminder letters or expect GP's to send you to be screened as this really isn't the case.¬†

Fast forward to January 2021 and my Dad is responding well to hormone treatment and we're enjoying everyday as much as we possibly can do in this crazy world that we're currently living in. Together, as a family we are fighting this awful disease head on and we won't be beaten. Positivity is key!¬†

I have set myself five challenges which are going to physically, mentally and emotionally test me over the next few months. Having the amazing charity Macmillan and my Dad pushing me on, these challenges shall help me to stay focused and determined! I shall be giving each challenge 110%. In the process I shall be raising money to help more families and cancer patients through Macmillan. The work Macmillan do is incredible, just to be able to help one family would be amazing! Together, we can beat cancer, we just need to raise awareness of how important it is to look after our bodies and to take charge of our bodies when it means the most!¬†

‚≠êChallenge 1: Cycle to Cornwall 350 miles! (Via home exercise bike in my livingroom!) - February¬†

‚≠êChallenge 2: Climb Mount Snowdown (Via my stairs at home!) - March¬†

‚≠êChallenge 3: Run 100KM - April¬†

‚≠êChallenge 4: Sponsored silence for 24hrs! - May¬†

‚≠êChallenge 5: Giving up the goodies for 1 month. Bye bye sweets, chocolate, crisps, sausage rolls, take aways and alcohol! - June¬†

I shall also be doing a few fun, family activities/games that everyone can join in with! I'm also hoping to set myself a few more challenges throughout the year.¬†

Thank you everyone for your support.¬†

Any donation will be extremely appreciated! However, if I could encourage just one person to be screened for cancer this would mean the world!¬†

Charlotte¬† xxx

story:
The Boyling Family's lives changed forever in October 2017 when Lisa went to the doctors with a chronic headache. Urgent tests, scans and an MRI discovered a small mass in Lisa‚Äôs right frontal lobe and surgery confirmed that the tumour was a right frontal Glioblastoma (WHO grade 4), unmethylated, which is the worst case scenario in the form of a brain tumour - the most aggressive type which claims 80% of patients within a year of being diagnosed.

Obviously this was absolutely devastating news to Lisa and her family, especially cruel as Lisa had worked as a Nurse Practitioner for the NHS in Brighton and Horsham for over 30 years, a job which she loved and immediately had to stop. An additional blow was dealt as she could no longer drive and Lisa lost her independence.

Soon after the diagnosis Lisa started a six week course of chemoradiotherapy followed by a course of Temozolomide Chemo tablets, however another MRI in June 2018 revealed suspicions of progressive disease rather than pseudo progression. It was decided to proceed with second line chemotherapy in the form of a PCV regimen. The treatment was brutal, with very bad side effects. Lisa completed three treatment cycles and was then referred to Charing Cross Hospital where she was offered further surgery and the chance to embark on a trail treatment of Chemo tablets and a plant based product by the name of Sativex. Further surgery was performed in December 2018 which went well and the surgeon was able to remove more tumour than he had first envisaged.

Although the surgery was a success there was never going to be a positive outcome and unfortunately Lisa started to deteriorate and before long she was receiving exceptional care from the Macmillan nurses from the Midhurst branch. On the 21st May 2019 Lisa lost her battle with her brain tumour.

Lisa¬†wanted people to raise money to support these charities so that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm doing. Please support me to honour Lisa‚Äôs memory.

story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise ¬£250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

After sampling some of the finer blends of Bunnahabhain, we made our way back to the main road. With the beautiful Paps of Jura in the background, he couldn‚Äôt have picked a finer spot. My mum said it was the expensive whiskey that did it!!
Every penny of our fundraising will go to the British Heart Foundation on life saving research and support for heart patients and the risk factors that cause them.

story:
I‚Äôve done the BHF Dechox for a number of years, the last time back in 2017 where I was incredibly thankful to raise over ¬£200.¬†

Each time I do it, I‚Äôll be honest, it gets harder. I know I‚Äôll ¬†have cravings for the 1st week. The second week I‚Äôll face the challenge of telling myself I‚Äôm nearly half way there (when I‚Äôm not) and then from there on in, as the cravings settle, I‚Äôll become impatient for it to end.¬†

It‚Äôs only chocolate! Most will think it‚Äôs not exactly challenging (usually those without a sweet tooth). ¬†Well actually this year I‚Äôve chosen to do chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks which will include my favourite tipple gin and lemonade. It probably doesn‚Äôt seem like a challenge, but for me it will be a personal one. Life doesn‚Äôt always bring you flowers but sometimes my sweet tooth brings me a little bit of happiness. A whole month without some comfort, especially in these lockdown times, can seem like forever and very sad.

The BHF are a charity I try and give back to. I lost my Dad back in 2003 and in today‚Äôs world with the advances the charity have made in their research and technologies, he‚Äôd probably have been saved and still be here. Since then, my grandad‚Äôs life was saved through to scientific knowledge and the wonderful skills of the cardiologists who were better equipped. I also had an experience that still lives with me where an appointment to have my nails done lead to me working with another to save a passerby‚Äôs life when her heart stopped. Would I have been able to do that without the valuable work of the BHF? Would I have known the signs and symptoms to look out for?¬†

We all have a heart and despite the great sadnesses that surround us all individually and collectively, we all deserve to live to see happiness and better days again.

Please, if you have a few spare pence, please consider donating and sponsoring me for my BHF Dechox 2021 or perhaps even joining me on the month of hell for some solidarity to help raise more when you become a fundraiser yourself.¬†

Love, (with my heart!)¬†

Katie x

story:
Hi Everyone, I've decided to take on this challenge of running a minimum of 56 miles across February in support of Cancer Research UK.

Its such a privilege to be able to do this, with all the lockdowns we face I think we could all do a little more to help ourselves and more importantly to help others around us. So I jumped at the opportunity to be involved and help raise money for such an amazing cause that's close to everyone's heart and lives.

I lost my Dad a little while back and it crushed my world, devastated me and changed my life forever. My Dad would now be 53 years young if he was here today. Unfortunately I lost my dad through multiple illness's that could not be helped. I'm sure there's many others out there in similar circumstances or that will face them circumstances in the future or will know somebody who will or who does already. it happens more often than not in todays day and age. So if I can help to raise as much money as possible to help someone to not go through similar to what I did or to preserve their life and time here on this earth with loved ones to make more memories and make it as best as possible then here I am!

Me and my father had a personal joke/bet between us, he said I would never get my weight down to a certain point - 75kg. At the time I was over 106kg. more into weights and meant I was running like a bus with 3 flat tyres. 23/01/2021 was the day I conquered that goal. Now I have completed that I know he used to love boxing and running, so I am now taking on a running challenge as it keeps us close!

all it takes is one person to make a difference! I will be making that difference starting February 1st 2021.

100% of all donations that are received will go directly to Cancer Research UK.¬†

as its a tough time in society I understand not everyone has large amounts of spare cash so I appreciate every token and gesture no matter how big or small! it all goes a long way in helping to make a difference in others lives!

if you want to keep up with my February journey I will be posting updates along the way! more updates will be found on my social media platform on instagram @JCPT23

Thank you for taking the time out to visit my JustGiving page. Please forward this on to others so this reaches as many eyes as possible in hope to raise as much awareness for this amazing life changing cause. if you are in a tough position please just forward my page on to others who may be able to help! its just as good. story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Cancer Research has always been a charity close to our hearts and after John passing away 12 years ago.¬† With heavy hearts we have set this page up for anyone that would like to donate and pay their kind respects to mum who we sadly lost on 15th January after a short illness.¬†


As children... John and I never needed anything as Mum loved to do everything for us as kids, but she also taught us important life skills and how to look after our own family.¬† As a Nanna, Sam was the luckiest boy in the world ... Mum just repeated everything she did for John and I but this time, he was her little solider and they had an amazing special bond.¬† Mum and dad were married for¬† 48 years and truly loved each other and were best friends.... I'd often hear mum call dad 'mate' and they clearly had the respect and love for each other and was truly made to be together.


Family... mum being the oldest of 4 brothers and a sister, family celebrations was always a fabulous event with plenty of laughs and drinking fun, there was a story to take away.


Friends... mum loved life, loved being with friends and loved making people laugh.¬† She was a straight talking lady, but people loved her for that and ..............


Unfortunately due to the current circumstances we are unable to welcome people to the funeral but if you would like to offer kind donations Dad, Matt, Sam, myself and our family would be truly grateful xx

story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

story: My Grandad was suddenly taken ill with breathing problems and was quickly diagnosed with pulmonary fibrosis. He got sick very quickly requiring oxygen and a lot of support. After being discharged from Hospital he was required to be put into a care home but as a family we were not going to let that happen. Grandad went to live with my mum and Dad and received care from them. As Grandad got worse and more confused towards the end my mum and Dad were very tired emotionally and physically. They got in touch with Marie Curie who arranged for a carer to come to the house for night time support so my Parents could get some much needed sleep. It‚Äôs amazing how different a bit of sleep can make you feel. Myself and Danny want to get healthier this year so have decided we are going to do this challenge and hopefully raise some money for a great cause too. Especially at the moment charity‚Äôs are struggling as not able to do there normal fundraising events so by supporting things like this is will be a massive help and they can continue to give the support to other family‚Äôs who need it too. Thank you for your support xx

story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.
